Package silhouette.constraints

The constraint package provides a way to write spreadsheet-like formulas that can be used to compute the properties of Silhouette shapes.

Package silhouette.constraints Description

The constraint package provides a way to write spreadsheet-like formulas that can be used to compute the properties of Silhouette shapes. Formulas are particularly helpful in aligning objects. In Silhouette, a formula is a function that computes the value of a property based on the values of other properties. If the values of any of these other properties is changed, the formula is automatically re-evaluated. Silhouette provides a large number of pre-defined formulas (also called constraints in Silhouette) that describe many of the geometric relationlships a programmer might want to specify:

  1. Constraints for Rectangular Objects
    • sameWidth: Makes an object be the same width as a reference object.
    • sameHeight: Makes an object be the same height as a reference object.
    • alignCenterX: Horizontally centers an object within a reference object.
    • alignCenterY: Vertically centers an object within a reference object.
    • alignLeft: Aligns the left side of an object with the left side of a reference object.
    • alignRight: Aligns the right side of an object with the right side of a reference object.
    • alignTop: Aligns the top side of an object with the top side of a reference object.
    • alignBottom: Aligns the bottom side of an object with the bottom side of a reference object.
    • alignAfter: Horizontally positions an object to the right of a reference object.
    • alignBefore: Horizontally positions an object to the left of a reference object.
    • alignOver: Vertically positions an object on top of a reference object.
    • alignUnder: Vertically positions an object under a reference object.
  2. Constraints for Line Objects
    • attachX1ToLeft: Attaches the x1 endpoint of a line to the left side of a reference object.
    • attachX1ToCenter: Attaches the x1 endpoint of a line to the center of a reference object.
    • attachX1ToRight: Attaches the x1 endpoint of a line to the right side of a reference object.
    • attachX2ToLeft: Attaches the x2 endpoint of a line to the left side of a reference object.
    • attachX2ToCenter: Attaches the x2 endopoint of a line to the center of a reference object.
    • attackX2ToRight: Attaches the x2 endpoint of a line to the right side of a reference object
    • attachY1ToTop: Attaches the y1 endpoint of a line to the top of a reference object.
    • attachY1ToCenter: Attaches the y1 endpoint of a line to the center of a reference object.
    • attachY1ToBottom: Attaches the y1 endpoint of a line to the bottom of a reference object.
    • attachY2ToTop: Attaches the y2 endpoint of a line to the top of a reference object.
    • attachY2ToCenter: Attaches the y2 endpoint of a line to the center of a reference object.
    • attachY2ToBottom: Attaches the y2 endpoint of a line to the bottom of a reference object.
    • attachPt1toClippedCenterPt: Attaches the first endpoint of a line to the point where the line intersects an object. The constraint assumes that the line extends from the center of a reference object to the center of the object to which the endpoint should be attached.
    • attachPt2toClippedCenterPt: Attaches the second endpoint of a line to the point where the line intersects an object. The constraint assumes that the line extends from the center of a reference object to the center of the object to which the endpoint should be attached.
    • attachPt1ToNearestCompassPt: Attaches the first endpoint to one of the eight compass points on an object. The constraint requires a reference object so that it knows from where the line originates.
    • attachPt2ToNearestCompassPt: Attaches the second endpoint to one of the eight compass points on an object. The constraint requires a reference object so that it knows from where the line originates.

Writing a Formula

The programmer writes a formula by subclassing the constraint class and overriding the formula method. The formula method can include any code that would be written in an ordinary function and should explicitly set whatever properties the formula computes. For example, suppose the programmer wants to write a formula that centers a label within a frame object. The label and the frame both belong to a composite shape and the frame is named "frame". Then the programmer can write:

class centerText extends silhouette.constraint {
    public void formula(constrainedObject self) {
        RectangleShape frame = (RectangleShape)(getParent().getShape("frame"));
        TextShape label = (TextShape)self;
        self.setLeft(frame.getCenterX() - self.getWidth()/2);
        self.setTop(frame.getCenterY() - self.getHeight()/2);
    }
}

self is a pointer to the object to which the constraint is attached. self typically needs to be cast to the appropriate object type before it can be used.

Attaching a Formula to an Object

A formula is activated by attaching the formula to the appropriate object using the addConstraint method. For example, the following line of code attaches the centerText constraint to the label object:

label.addConstraint(new centerText());
